item.title: Potential jurors in Trump’s hush money trial break down crying, express anxiety during tense jury selection
item.description: Prosecutors could outline questions for former president as jury selection nears end in hush money case

media:content.media:text: Donald Trump at Manhattan criminal court in New York City.
media:content.media:description: Donald Trump at Manhattan criminal court in New York City, on April 19, 2024.

item.title: Twisted truths and a fundraising boost: How Trump tried to control his first week in court
item.dc:creator: Matt Dixon and Joe Murphy
item.description: On the first day of the trial, Trump's campaign raised $1.6 million in small-dollar donations, a campaign official told NBC News.

media:content.media:text: Donald Trump speaks to the media before attending jury selection
media:content.media:description: Donald Trump before jury selection on the second day of his trial at Manhattan criminal court on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel and Iran stay largely silent after limited retaliatory strike
item.description: A person familiar with the situation told NBC News that Israel carried out an operation in Iran. Earlier, Israeli officials notified U.S. officials that a response was coming.

media:content.media:text: A man walks past a banner depicting missiles along a street in Tehran
media:content.media:description: A man walks past a banner depicting missiles along a street in Tehran on April 19, 2024.

item.title: Tesla recalls almost 4,000 Cybertrucks over faulty accelerator
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith
item.description: Tesla is recalling almost 4,000 of its flagship Cybertrucks to fix a potentially dangerous fault with their accelerators' pedals.

media:content.media:text: A Tesla Cybertruck In Los Angeles
media:content.media:description: The NHTSA has issued a recall for cybertrucks after a video of an accelerator pedal problem spread across social media.

item.title: A sheriff, a felon and a conspiracy theorist walk into a hotel. They're there for the same conference.
item.dc:creator: Brandy Zadrozny
item.description: The Constitutional Sheriffs and Peace Officers Association conference in Las Vegas drew felons, disgraced politicians, election deniers and conspiracy theorists.

media:content.media:text: Sheriff Glenn of Hamilton of Sierra County, NM at the CSPOA Conference (Constitutional Sheriffs and Peace Officers Association) in Las Vegas, NV.
media:content.media:description: Former Sierra County, New Mexico, Sheriff Glenn Hamilton, part of a fringe group that sees sheriffs as more powerful than the federal government.

media:content.media:text: Tom Hamner, who served time in prison for “interfering with law enforcement” on Jan. 6, 2021, prays with his wife.
media:content.media:description: Tom Hamner, who served time in prison for “interfering with law enforcement” on Jan. 6, 2021, prays with his wife.

media:content.media:text: Candidates for local office mingled with lawmen and far-right activists.
media:content.media:description: Candidates for local office mingled with lawmen and far-right activists.

media:content.media:text: Sponsors sold pro-Trump merch between speeches.
media:content.media:description: Sponsors sold pro-Trump merch between speeches.

media:content.media:text: A CSPOA attendee shows off her bling.
media:content.media:description: A CSPOA attendee shows off her bling.

media:content.media:text: Richard Mack is known among friends and fans as the sheriff who beat President Bill Clinton’s Brady Act.
media:content.media:description: Richard Mack is known among friends and fans as the sheriff who beat President Bill Clinton’s Brady Act.

media:content.media:text: Klickitat County, Washington, Sheriff Bob Songer keeps his posse at the ready, as a potential militia.
media:content.media:description: Klickitat County, Washington, Sheriff Bob Songer keeps his posse at the ready, as a potential militia.

media:content.media:text: Former Rep. Steve King found a friendly audience at the CSPOA Conference.
media:content.media:description: Former Rep. Steve King found a friendly audience at the CSPOA Conference.

media:content.media:text: King spoke of the "globalist" threat to America.
media:content.media:description: King spoke of the "globalist" threat to America.

media:content.media:text: Songer prays with conference goers.
media:content.media:description: Songer prays with conference goers.

media:content.media:text: Songer only enforces laws he determines to be constitutional.
media:content.media:description: Songer only enforces laws he determines to be constitutional.

media:content.media:text: Glenn Hamilton once deputized an entire church congregation in order to flout the governor’s Covid-19 rules.
media:content.media:description: Glenn Hamilton once deputized an entire church congregation in order to flout the governor’s Covid-19 rules.

media:content.media:text: Wayne Allyn Root promotes the racist “great replacement" theory.
media:content.media:description: Wayne Allyn Root promotes the racist “great replacement" theory.

media:content.media:text: Songer, left, and CSPOA CEO Sam Bushman, center, mingle at the CSPOA conference.
media:content.media:description: Songer, left, and CSPOA CEO Sam Bushman, center, mingle at the CSPOA conference.

media:content.media:text: A drone acts as a prop for a conspiracy-filled presentation on child trafficking.
media:content.media:description: A drone acts as a prop for a conspiracy-filled presentation on child trafficking.

media:content.media:text: Retired Army Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn points at members of the media.
media:content.media:description: Retired Army Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn points at members of the media.

media:content.media:text: Flynn, among friends, at the CSPOA conference.
media:content.media:description: Flynn, among friends, at the CSPOA conference.

media:content.media:text: Richard Fleming prepares for his presentation, in which he claims Covid vaccines are "bioweapons."
media:content.media:description: Richard Fleming prepares for his presentation, in which he claims Covid vaccines are "bioweapons."

media:content.media:text: Attendees participate in the invocation.
media:content.media:description: Attendees participate in the invocation.

media:content.media:text: Mike Lindell, CEO of MyPillow, says sheriffs "don't know the power they have."
media:content.media:description: Mike Lindell, CEO of MyPillow, says sheriffs "don't know the power they have."

media:content.media:text: Paul Moore, candidate for sheriff in Clackamas County, Oregon, said he was "there to learn."
media:content.media:description: Paul Moore, candidate for sheriff in Clackamas County, Oregon, said he was "there to learn."

media:content.media:text: An attendee at the CSPOA conference takes a break.
media:content.media:description: An attendee at the CSPOA conference takes a break.

media:content.media:text: CSPOA founder Richard Mack kisses his wife.
media:content.media:description: CSPOA founder Richard Mack kisses his wife.

item.title: House tees up votes on Ukraine and Israel aid as Speaker Johnson defies his right flank
item.dc:creator: Sahil Kapur and Rebecca Kaplan and Kyle Stewart and Lori Rampani and Syedah Asghar
item.description: The House advanced four separate bills, including aid for Ukraine and Israel after months of delay and a bill that could ban TikTok in the U.S.

media:content.media:text: Mike Johnson
media:content.media:description: Mike Johnson on April 17, 2024 in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Eating within limited hours can help with weight loss — but that may be because it simply cuts calories
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A new study compared how much weight people lost on time-restricted versus regular meal schedules.

media:content.media:text: Vegetables and fruits on a plate on a light background
media:content.media:description: A new study found that when researchers controlled the number of calories people consumed, both time-restricted and regular eating schedules resulted in similar degrees of weight loss.

item.title: Swifties praise 'The Tortured Poets Department' as it blasts to the top of U.S. charts
item.description: Swifties are ready for the new album's release at midnight ET.

media:content.media:text: Cover images for "The Tortured Poets Department" by Taylor Swift.
media:content.media:description: Cover images for "The Tortured Poets Department" by Taylor Swift.

item.title: New FAA rest rules to address 'fatigue' issues with air traffic controllers
item.dc:creator: Rob Wile
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration is instituting new rest rules for U.S. air traffic controllers to address fatigue issues that may be degrading air safety.

media:content.media:text: The air traffic control tower at Chicago's Midway International Airport.
media:content.media:description: The air traffic control tower at Chicago's Midway International Airport.

item.title: New exhibit in New York re-creates Israeli music festival attacked on Oct. 7
item.dc:creator: Daniel Arkin and Chloe Melas
item.description: The objects bear the scars of a massacre.

media:content.media:text: Nova Exhibition Installation
media:content.media:description: Nova survivor Natalie Sanandaji and Reef Peretz, chairman of the Nova Foundation, look at destroyed cars taken from the Nova festival on display in New York City.

media:content.media:text: Nova Exhibition Installation
media:content.media:description: Television screens display videos of the attack.

media:content.media:text: Nova Exhibition Installation
media:content.media:description: Camping items taken from the festival re-create the festival layout.

media:content.media:text: Shoes on display in the "Lost & Found" area of the exhibit.
media:content.media:description: Shoes on display in the "Lost & Found" area of the exhibit.

item.title: U.S. likely to enact a law soon that could ban TikTok nationwide
item.dc:creator: Scott Wong and Kyle Stewart and Rebecca Kaplan and Frank Thorp V and Kate Santaliz and Sahil Kapur
item.description: Legislation that could ban TikTok in the U.S. unless it cuts ties with its Chinese parent company is on a path to quickly be signed into law.

media:content.media:text: Boy looks at an iPhone screen showing TikTok logo
media:content.media:description: A bill that could ban TikTok in the U.S. is on a glidepath to passage.

item.description: Watch live coverage as President Biden delivers remarks to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers construction and maintenance conference.

item.title: Another Republican joins effort to oust Mike Johnson, putting the speaker in real peril
item.dc:creator: Kyle Stewart and Julie Tsirkin and Ali Vitali and Sarah Mimms
item.description: A third House Republican has signed onto an effort to oust Speaker Mike Johnson from power, giving his opponents the votes they'd need to remove the Republican leader unless Democrats stepped in to save him.

media:content.media:text: Image: Speaker of the House Mike Johnson
media:content.media:description: Speaker Mike Johnson faces a significant threat to his job.

item.title: Our editor’s favorite over-ear headphones of 2024
item.dc:creator: Henry St. Leger and Terri Williams and Harry Rabinowitz
item.description: We tested over a dozen models from top brands like Sony, Bose, Apple, JBL, Soundcore and more. Find our top picks for travel, noise-canceling and more.

media:content.media:text: Over-ear headphones often have better sound quality and stronger noise-canceling compared to earbuds and on-ear options.
media:content.media:description: Over-ear headphones often have better sound quality and stronger noise-canceling compared to earbuds and on-ear options.

item.title: Israel carries out limited strikes on Iran, with the extent of damage unclear
item.dc:creator: Anna Schecter and Courtney Kube and Mosheh Gains and Dan De Luce and Andrea Mitchell and Daniel Arkin
item.description: Israeli forces carried out an operation in Iran on Thursday night, according to a person familiar with the matter.

media:content.media:text: Israeli Iron Dome air defense system launches to intercept missiles fired from Iran, in central Israel on Sunday, April 14, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Israeli Iron Dome air defense system launches to intercept missiles fired from Iran, in central Israel on Sunday, April 14, 2024.

item.title: Chinese runner’s win is revoked after investigation into Beijing Half Marathon
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: The results of Beijing’s half marathon were canceled after an investigation found that three African runners had slowed down to allow a Chinese athlete to win.

media:content.media:text: Half-marathon in Beijing
media:content.media:description: From left, Willy Mnangat and Robert Keter of Kenya, He Jie of China and Dejene Hailu Bikila of Ethiopia approach the finish line in the Beijing Half Marathon on Sunday.

item.title: Woman who sent Harry Styles 8,000 cards in a month sentenced to 14 weeks in jail for stalking
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith and David K. Li and Meriam Bouarrouj
item.description: A 35-year-old woman who sent 8,000 greeting cards in one month to Harry Styles admitted to stalking the pop superstar and was sentenced to 14 weeks behind bars.

media:content.media:text: Harry Styles
media:content.media:description: Harry Styles in 2022.

item.title: Scientists push new paradigm of animal consciousness, saying even insects may be sentient
item.dc:creator: Evan Bush
item.description: Far more animals than previously thought likely have consciousness, top scientists say in a new declaration — including fish, lobsters and octopus. Recent research backs them up.

media:content.media:text: Tropical Fish
media:content.media:description: A cleaner Wrasse fish.

media:content.media:text: Lobster

item.title: U.S. deports about 50 Haitians to nation hit with gang violence, ending monthslong pause in flights
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The Biden administration sent about 50 Haitians back to their country on Thursday marking the first deportation flight in several months to the nation struggling with gang violence.

media:content.media:text: Armed police officers monitor a street
media:content.media:description: Police officers monitor a street after gang violence in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Nearly half of China's major cities are sinking, researchers say
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Nearly half of China’s major cities are suffering “moderate to severe” levels of subsidence, putting millions of people at risk of flooding, a study found.

media:content.media:text: Members of the Peoples Armed Police wade through receding floodwaters as they help to retrieve goods from a building in Zhuozhou, China
media:content.media:description: Members of the People’s Armed Police wading through receding floodwaters in Zhuozhou, China, last year.

item.title: Ecuador's President Noboa looks set to win vote on new security measures
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Ecuador’s President Daniel Noboa looks set to win a referendum on Sunday that asks voters to support new security measures to fight rising violence, although recent power cuts could pose a threat to the ‘yes’ vote.

media:content.media:text: Daniel Noboa in Madrid
media:content.media:description: Pres. Daniel Noboa is asking voters on Sunday to approve new measures as the country grapples with rising violence and the rise of cocaine-smuggling gangs.
